questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of skin fragility and blistering on sun-exposed areas. He also reports significant liver disease history and excessive alcohol consumption. Laboratory tests show elevated porphyrins in urine. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis related to porphyrin metabolism. Which of the following types of porphyria is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Porphyria cutanea tarda

 

Option B:

 

  • The disease is due to deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.
  • Precipitating factors -Hepatic injury caused by environmental (ethanol) and infectious (hepatitis B virus) agents and exposure to sunlight.
  • Porphyrin accumulates in circulation leads to cutaneous symptoms and gets excreted in urine, turning it red to brown.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acute intermittent porphyria: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen I synthase; C/F-Abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with increased urinary ALA and PBG.

 

Option C: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen III synthase; C/F- Photosensitivity with increased uroporphyrin I in urinary, faecal, and red cells.

 

Option D: Hereditary coproporphyria: Deficiency of Coproporphyrinogen oxidase; C/F-Photosensitivity, abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and faecal coproporphyrin III increased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common form of porphyria and is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 274.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): AIP (acute intermittent porphyria) has abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric features as common presentation.
 

Reasoning (R): The above symptoms are due to accumulation of ALA and PBG. ALA inhibits ATPase in the nervous system leads to conduction paralysis.

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of the Assertion and Reasoning provided?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A.                                                

 

Option D:

 

  • The defective enzyme in acute intermittent porphyria is hydroxymethylbilane synthase (uroporphyrinogen I synthase),
  • ALA and porphobilinogen accumulate in body tissues and fluids
  • C/F: Abdominal and neurological manifestations like sensory and motor disturbances, confusion, agitation and psychiatric problems.
  • No photosensitivity

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) is marked by a lack of porphobilinogen deaminase, causing delta-aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen buildup, leading to abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. This is due to ALA's neurotoxicity, which inhibits ATPase in neurons, resulting in neuronal dysfunction and paralysis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 328-329

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a notably disfigured face, pronounced photosensitivity, stained teeth, and laboratory tests revealing elevated levels of Coproporphyrin-I. Based on these clinical findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uroporphyrinogen III Synthase                               

 

Option B:

 

  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria has AR inheritance
  • The defective enzyme - uroporphyrinogen III synthase leads to increase in levels of porphyrin I
  • Their excretion in urine makes the urine dark red in colour (port wine appearance)
  • Reactive oxygen species are the cause for attacks of dermatitis and scarring which leads to severe disfigurement referred to as ‘monkey face’. Also photosensitivity is reported.
  • When UV light is reflected onto teeth a red fluorescence is seen; this is called erythrodontia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Uroporphyrinogen Synthase - A deficiency in this enzyme would not lead to the specific accumulation of Coproporphyrin-I, nor would it directly result in the clinical syndrome described.

 

Option C: Uroporphyrinogen Decarboxylase - Deficiency in this enzyme leads to Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (PCT), the most common type of porphyria, which presents with skin fragility and blistering on sun-exposed areas, but not the severe disfigurement or erythrodontia seen in this case.

 

Option D: Coproporphyrinogen Oxidase - Deficiency of this enzyme results in Hereditary Coproporphyria, which can cause photosensitivity and neurological symptoms but does not typically present with the severe facial disfigurement or stained teeth as described in the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria (CEP), a rare disorder caused by a deficiency in Uroporphyrinogen III Synthase. The accumulation of specific porphyrins leads to symptoms including photosensitivity, facial disfigurement, and stained teeth, emphasizing the critical role of the heme biosynthesis pathway in maintaining normal physiological functions and the diverse clinical manifestations that can arise from its disruption.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 327-329

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, who works as a golf instructor, presents to the clinic with sudden onset of painful blisters on the backs of his hands. He reports no recent exposure to skin irritants. His medical history is significant for complex partial seizures following a head injury, for which he has been taking phenytoin. He admits to consuming alcohol on a weekly basis. Laboratory tests reveal reddish-orange urine with elevated levels of uroporphyrin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Porphyria cutanea tarda

 

Option D:

 

  • The disease is due to deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.
  • Precipitating factors - Hepatic injury caused by environmental (ethanol) and infectious (hepatitis B virus) agents and exposure to sunlight.
  • Porphyrin accumulates in circulation leads to cutaneous symptoms and gets excreted in urine, turns it red to brown.
  • Treatment of this patient’s seizure disorder with phenytoin → increased synthesis of d-amino levulinic acid synthase → increased uroporphyrinogen, on which the deficient enzyme acts. The laboratory and clinical findings are not seen in other porphyria’s.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acute intermittent porphyria: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen I synthase; C/F-Abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with increased urinary ALA and PBG.
 

Option B: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen III synthase; C/F- Photosensitivity with increased uroporphyrin I in urinary, fecal, and red cells.


Option C: Hereditary coproporphyria: Deficiency of Coproporphyrinogen oxidase; C/F-Photosensitivity, abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and faecal coproporphyrin III increased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common form of porphyria and is characterized by photosensitivity leading to skin fragility and blistering on sun-exposed areas, such as the backs of the hands. Factors that can precipitate PCT include alcohol consumption, liver disease, and estrogen use. Additionally, certain medications, such as phenytoin, can exacerbate the condition. The elevated levels of uroporphyrin in the urine, along with the clinical presentation and history, are indicative of PCT.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 280.

Ans. B) Congenital erythropoietic porphyria                            

 

Option B)

 

  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria has AR inheritance
  • The defective enzyme – uroporphyrinogen III synthase leads to increase in levels of porphyrin I
  • Their excretion in urine makes the urine dark red in colour (port wine appearance)
  • Reactive oxygen species are the cause for attacks of dermatitis and scarring which leads to severe disfigurement referred to as ‘monkey face’. Also photosensitivity is reported.
  • When UV light is reflected onto teeth a red fluorescence is seen; this is called erythrodontia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP): Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen I synthase; C/F-Abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with increased urinary ALA and PBG.

 

Option C: Porphyria cutanea tarda: Deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. Porphyrin accumulates in circulation leads to cutaneous symptoms and gets excreted in urine, turns it red to brown.

 

Option D: Hereditary coproporphyria: Deficiency of Coproporphyrinogen oxidase; C/F-Photosensitivity, abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and faecal coproporphyrin III increased.

 

Educational objective:

 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP), also known as Günther's disease, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the defective synthesis of heme, leading to the accumulation of porphyrins in various tissues, including the bones and teeth. The clinical findings of reddish-brown discoloration of teeth (erythrodontia) that fluoresce under UV light, and red urine that may darken upon exposure to light, are pathognomonic for CEP.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 327-329.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with mild anemia, photosensitivity, and skin blistering. His symptoms exacerbated while on rifampin treatment for a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. Considering his clinical presentation, which biochemical pathway is most likely impaired in this boy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heme synthesis

 

Option D:

 

  • The boy has porphyria, a reduced ability to synthesize heme.
  • The super sensitivity to the sun is due to the presence of heme precursors in skin cells that are easily converted to radial form by the energy in sunlight and which severely damage the cell.
  • The drug boy is taking is metabolized via a cytochrome P450 system, which is induced when the drug first enters the circulation.
  • Induction of P450 systems induced the synthesis of heme leading to increased concentrations of the heme intermediates and an increased sensitivity to the effects of these intermediates as induced by sunlight.
  • The anemia is due to reduced heme levels in the red blood cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glycogen synthesis: Defects in glycogen synthesis or its metabolism usually present with muscle cramps, exercise intolerance, or hypoglycemia, not photosensitivity or skin blistering.

 

Option B: Fatty acid oxidation: Disorders in fatty acid oxidation typically manifest with hypoketotic hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, or muscle weakness, not the symptoms described in the vignette.

 

Option C: DNA repair: While defects in DNA repair mechanisms can lead to photosensitivity (e.g., xeroderma pigmentosum), they would not explain the anemia or the worsening of symptoms with rifampin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical manifestations of disorders of heme synthesis, such as porphyrias, which can present with photosensitivity, skin blistering, and anemia. It is also important to recognize that certain medications, like rifampin, can exacerbate these conditions by inducing hepatic enzymes and thus increasing the demand for heme synthesis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 271.
